Tania Bruguera, Juan Orozco, and Seungho Seo (0814) are among the artists who have been selected to participate in the 2020 Venice Architecture Biennale. The six-day event, which will be held at La Scala, Italy, will feature works by seventy-three nominees; the chosen ten finalists are Bruguera, Orozco, and Seo, who collectively received more than five thousand votes. The exhibition reopens on March 3, 2020.The exhibition will feature new works by forty-five artists and twenty-six curators, including Cécile Béchard (New York–based), Gianluca Raffaele (Venezuela), Zinedine Leibovici (New York–based), Luca Giunta (Venezuela), Riccardo Poggioli (Italy), Andrea Hahn (Germany), and Anish Kapoor (India). The next Biennial should mark the centenary of the Russian–Austrian artist Matvei Rublev. Rublev, who often depicted everyday life in his surrealist paintings, has been called a pioneer of the post-Soviet generation and has had numerous exhibitions organized by him. The event will be co-organized by the Center for Contemporary Art Research in Moscow, the Institute of Modern Art in Moscow, and the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC.The inaugural edition, hosted at the MOST Pavilion in Singapore in 2009, was hosted by Anson Haroon and cost $3 million. Over the course of its three-hundred-year history, the event has attracted many thousand visitors. In recent years, the event has had several iterations, including the “Rostov Triennale” (2009), “BSTM: 50 Years of Drawing” (2012), and “Rostov 1932” (2013), and the “Rostov Cinema” (2015). September 9 marks the seventeenth edition, which will be held at the AMCA in London.

The National Arts Center (NAC) in Washington, DC, has received a $2.5 million donation from Artnet. The gift, made on behalf of two NAC board members, Nancy and Marc Glimcher, as well as NAC cofounder and CEO Matthew Teitelbaum, was made on behalf of the NAC's Artists’ Union, which was established in 1991 to support artists who were struggling financially. “Nancy and Marc were committed to supporting artists in Washington, DC, and were delighted to receive this handsome gift from the NAC,” said NAC board president and CEO Marc Glimcher. “We are grateful for the generous support of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA), the National Endowment for Cultural and Creative Preservation (NEA), and the National Endowment for the Humanities (NEH).”The donation comes a little more than a year after NAC board president and CEO Nancy Glimcher and cofounders Marc Glimcher and Nancy Teitelbaum awarded a $1.8 million grant to the Arts’ Institute (AI) in Santa Fe, New Mexico.
